user_message:
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the: 1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter. 2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body. 3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body. 4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of init_response_body_data: ```c static int init_response_body_data (void) { if (0 != body_dyn_size) { body_dyn = (char *) malloc (body_dyn_size); if (NULL == body_dyn) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n"); return 0; } if (tool_params.medium) { /* Fill the body with HTML-like content */ size_t pos; size_t filler_pos; static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n"; static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } ``` Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function init_response_body_data: static size_t body_dyn_size ... static char *body_dyn = NULL ... #define MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(macro) (sizeof(macro)/sizeof(char)-1) ... static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n" ... static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n" ... static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n" Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only for-loop constructs are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 (well-formed for loops). The two code fragments above are the only for statements in the function and therefore are the items that must be investigated for compliance (initialization clause, loop-test clause side-effects and object usage, and iteration clause modifying only the loop counter; single loop counter not modified in the loop body). Other parts of the function are not for statements and thus are not applicable to Rule 14.2: - Memory allocation (malloc) and its NULL check do not affect for-loop clause formation. - memcpy calls and the subsequent pos adjustments are not for statements. - Declarations of body_header/body_filler/body_footer and the macro MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ expand to constant-size computations; they are not loop constructs (they may be used by the loops, but they themselves are not for-statements). - The if/else structure and return statement are control flow but not for loops. - Assignments to body_dyn outside or after the loops (e.g. pos += filler_pos) are not for-loop headers or iteration expressions. Therefore only the two for-loop fragments listed need investigation under Rule 14.2.
